heisig_chinese_memo: This kanji looks like the "s" of "self", looking at its own reflection in a mirror (reversed sideways), as if pondering about his "self".
heisig_story: The kanji carries the abstract sense of the self, the deep-down inner structure of the human person that mythology has often depicted as a snake - which is what the kanji shows pictographically. Be sure to keep it distinct from the similar keywords, oneself (frame 36) and I (frame 17).
koohiiStory1: This kanji looks like the "s" of "self", looking at its own reflection in a mirror (reversed sideways), as if pondering about his "self".
koohiiStory2: When Superman looks at himself in the mirror, this is what he sees on his chest.
WaniKani_Meaning_Mnemonic: The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for oneself first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means oneself as well.

chinese_mnemonics_deck__story: This kanji looks like the "s" of "self", looking at its own reflection in a mirror (reversed sideways), as if pondering about his "self".
humanum_full_description_en:
A buckled silk rope used for binding, braiding, and binding. The original meaning is a silk rope used for binding. It is the first text of " Ji " (see Zhu Fangpu, Gu Yankui). Later, it was used to express oneself and oneself (Gu Yankui believes that because he is the person who can restrain oneself most), and also used to be the sixth place in the heavenly stem, matching with the earth, to record the year, month, and day. According to the bounded string, the " discipline " of " self " can express the meanings of discipline, law, and discipline.

Inscriptions on Jia Jin and bamboo slips from the Warring States Period were used as heavenly stems to record the year, month and day. "Collection" 3649: "Jihai Bu" refers to the day of Jihai Zhen Bu. Chen Xihu: "Jiyou" refers to Jiyouri. "Sleeping Tiger Land Qin Bamboo Slips. Simplified 153: "March Month Jiyou", which means the day of March Jiyou. "Sleeping Tiger Land Qin Bamboo Slips. Japanese Book No. 67: "Jimao, you can cut trees." It means that you can cut trees on this day.

The Bamboo Slips of the Warring States Period and the Silk Script of Han Dynasty expressed themselves again. "Guodian Jane. "Yu Cong 3" Jane 5: "If you add to yourself without me (righteousness), you will not accept it." It means that unrighteous words and actions are imposed on oneself and will not be accepted. "Mawangdui. Line 123 of the Book of Political Strategists in the Warring States Period: "Three Jins regard the king as loving and loyal to oneself." "Mawangdui. The 206th line of Laozi's Second Edition: "The saint has no accumulation, if he thinks that he is a person, he (heavier) has; if he can give others, he has (more) more." The more I have; the more I have given others.

The ancient book " ji " often expresses oneself, such as "Mencius. "Gongsun Chou 1": "Da Shun has great Yan, goodness is with others, and he gives up himself and obeys others." "The Analects. "Yan Yuan": "Do not do to others what you do not want." "Book of Rites. Sacrifice": "Goodness is called people, and passing is called self."
humanum_short_description_en: Synopsis: The inscription " Ji " is like a silk rope that is bent and looped. The original meaning is a silk rope to tie things. It is the original text of " Ji ". Later, he expressed himself as the sixth heavenly stem.

Heisig: The kanji carries the abstract sense of the self, the deep-down inner structure of the human person that mythology has often depicted as a snake - which is what the kanji shows pictographically. Be sure to keep it distinct from the similar keywords, oneself (frame 36) and I (frame 17).
* As a primitive element, this kanji can be used for the snake - of which it is a pictograph - or any of the various concrete symbolic meanings the snake has in myth and fable.

A buckled silk rope used for binding, braiding, and binding. The original meaning is a silk rope used for binding. It is the first text of " Ji" (see Zhu Fangpu, Gu Yankui). Later, it was used to express oneself and oneself (Gu Yankui believes that because he is the person who can restrain oneself most), and also used to be the sixth place in the heavenly stem, matching with the earth, to record the year, month, and day. According to the bounded string, the " discipline" of " self" can express the meanings of discipline, law, and discipline. Inscriptions on Jia Jin and bamboo slips from the Warring States Period were used as heavenly stems to record the year, month and day. "Collection" 3649: "Jihai Bu" refers to the day of Jihai Zhen Bu. Chen Xihu: "Jiyou" refers to Jiyouri. "Sleeping Tiger Land Qin Bamboo Slips. Simplified 153: "March Month Jiyou", which means the day of March Jiyou. "Sleeping Tiger Land Qin Bamboo Slips. Japanese Book No. 67: "Jimao, you can cut trees." It means that you can cut trees on this day. The Bamboo Slips of the Warring States Period and the Silk Script of Han Dynasty expressed themselves again. "Guodian Jane. "Yu Cong 3" Jane 5: "If you add to yourself without me (righteousness), you will not accept it." It means that unrighteous words and actions are imposed on oneself and will not be accepted. "Mawangdui. Line 123 of the Book of Political Strategists in the Warring States Period: "Three Jins regard the king as loving and loyal to oneself." "Mawangdui. The 206th line of Laozi's Second Edition: "The saint has no accumulation, if he thinks that he is a person, he (heavier) has; if he can give others, he has (more) more." The more I have; the more I have given others. The ancient book " ji" often expresses oneself, such as "Mencius. "Gongsun Chou 1": "Da Shun has great Yan, goodness is with others, and he gives up himself and obeys others." "The Analects. "Yan Yuan": "Do not do to others what you do not want." "Book of Rites. Sacrifice": "Goodness is called people, and passing is called self."
